Blog.post: An excerpt from _Making a Living Without a Job: Winning Ways for Creating Work that You Love_ by Barbara J. Winter: When you are willing to invest in yourself and your ideas, you have put your money and time into the one thing that lasts a lifetime and can never be taken from you. Businessman and author Bob Conklin tells this story: "Twenty years ago, my wife and I evaluated all the ways we had spent and invested money. Stocks, cars, insurance, real estate, furniture, and all other major investments were scrutinized. Do you know what investments outdistanced others by an enormous percentage? Ourselves. Any investments in our growth or self-improvement had paid incredible returns. Books, courses, seminars, conventions - whatever the learning experience - had always returned far greater rewards than any other investment. The best investment in life is in your own self-development. It will pay off the greatest financial and emotional rewards." (page 65) Thanks to my dad for giving me this book!

I invented cereal salad, the breakfast food, but A. (E.'s girlfriend) is the one who coined the phrase. I think I wind up putting about a dozen different things in my cereal. To wit: 1. usually some kind of commercially prepared cereal: granola and/or something organic and low-wheat (actually, from this point on, in this and future posts, assume that most ingredients are organically grown) 2. oat bran (I actually like oat bran.) 3. puffed kamut and/or millet 4. raisins? 5. sunflower seeds 6. walnuts and/or cashews and/or pecans and/or almonds 7. vanilla and/or original Edensoy soymilk 8. cinnamon? often. cardamom? occasionally 9. hazelnut milk? oat milk? if I have some of one or the other, I'll add it. 10. shredded coconut 11. frozen blueberries, although never in combination with raisins. particularly useful when the only liquid is plan soymilk. 12. banana? eh. not so much recently. So it's a whole production. Funny: a dozen, on the nose. But that's not including sub-parts. The interesting thing is that since soy milk is sweeter than cow's milk, if you're using soy milk you can eat cereal that's been less sweetened. Well, maybe that *isn't* the interesting thing.

What if after we leave the synagogue all our prayers huddle together and talk about us? What if they reach consensus? What if a representative sneaks out the door and runs over to the other synagogue, to the mosque, to the church? What if prayers have conventions? Maybe that's God.

Just in case you were wondering, John Kerry's acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention lasted just about long enough for me to clean a long-neglected stove. I didn't touch the oven itself, but got to pretty much every other surface, including all the dials on the front of the stove. Six dials: 4 burners, one oven -- so what was the sixth one for? It said "grid." Yes, that's right. After living in this house since December, I discovered that my stove has a built-in griddle. And yes, I cleaned both the griddle and the griddle cover. Thanks, John. I used probably a quarter cup of baking soda. (Thanks to whoever told me that baking soda cuts grease.) Okay, maybe that's an exaggeration. I used a scrubbee cloth that I got from my Oma, perhaps from Israel. I washed it a bunch of times in the kitchen sink. I like this John Kerry guy. I have to say, I still don't think I'd recognize his face. No matter. Thanks to WHYY in Philly. This is the longest in a long time I've listened to anyone talking on the radio. News. I've been gradually building up to actually actively seeking out mass media news consumption. I have a personal custom of defrosting and cleaning out my fridge on September 11. Now I'm excited to see how my kitchen will benefit during this election season. And I hope that the energy and passion I put into cleaning up my kitchen will have some kind of karmic effect on the White House. Greetings and grease, Ilana
